channel.title: Theorems :: CIS 301 Textbook
channel.description: Definition A theorem in propositional logic is something that is always true with no need for premises. The truth table for a theorem is always a tautology – it is true for any truth assignment. To express a theorem as a sequent, we write: ⊢ (theorem)This shows that we are trying to prove our theorem with NO premises. Such a proof will always immediately begin with a subproof, as there are no premises to process.
